Award.AwardTitle: Eco-Systems Biology of Polyphosphate Accumulating Consortia

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0967646
McMahon

This NSF award by the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering program supports work to use a systems biology framework to understand the behavior of an engineered ecosystem. The ecosystem is a wastewater treatment process designed to biologically remove phosphorus from sewage in order to protect surface waters from excessive nutrient inputs. The organisms responsible for phosphorus removal (called Accumulibacter) use a unique and complex metabolism that is poorly understood. In this project, we will use novel techniques based in meta-omics to study gene expression at the level of the entire bacterial community in a laboratory scale wastewater treatment system. The integrative and holistic approach provided by systems biology will allow us to understand how different species of Accumulibacter regulate their biochemical pathways to maximize phosphorus removal from water. Finally, we will construct a computational model that can predict how the Accumulibacter metabolism functions under normal and perturbed conditions. This understanding will improve our ability to predict when and why wastewater treatment systems fail, but it will also serve as a powerful case study in the application of systems biology tools to bacterial communities that are engineered using ecological principles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research focused on a group of bacteria (known as "Accumulibacter") that help remove pollutants from wastewater. A systems-biology approach was used to study how their genetic content determines their behavior in wastewater treatment systems. 


Accumulibacter cannot be grown in isolation. Therefore, a community of bacteria enriched in Accumulibacter is used to study its physiology and ecology. These communities are powerful model systems and this work used the communities to demonstrate how systems-biology can be applied to organisms in a community context.


Genome sequences from two distinct but co-occurring Accumulibacter species were recovered from community DNA. Their sequences were compared to identify similarities and differences that are likely relevant to the organisms' activity. A set of highly controlled experiments revealed new metabolic "circuits" that control the behavior of the dominant species. The new understanding provided by this work allow engineers to use a more rational and deliberate design process when building wastewater treatment systems. Furthermore, the findings show that systems-biology principles can be used to study organisms within a community.


The project supported training of two engineering PhD students whose dissertations were based on this work. It also engaged 15 undergraduate students in research and several of these students have moved on to attend graduate school. Four of these students were members of groups that are underrepresented in engineering. Two new international collaborations were initiated through this work: one with Professor Per Nielsen at Aalborg University in Denmark, and one with Professor Francisco Rodriguez-Valera at Alicante University in Spain. The research also strengthened existing and ongoing collaborations with the Joint Genome Institute in California, who provided the DNA sequencing at no cost. Project team members engaged in outreach to pre-college (high-school and middle-school) children, introducing them to principles of biological wastewater treatment.
